data.title: Flickr: Discussing What GIMP scripts do you need
data.meta_description: The safest and most inclusive global community of photography enthusiasts. The best place for inspiration, connection, and sharing!

kr428 says:

Interesting question... actually, personally I like doing some scripting using gimp-python once in a while, but nothing too spectacular. However, looking at what a bunch of "average users" use their computers / imaging stuff for, I think there is a lot of room for plugins / scripts to automate tasks usually provided in a fast, convenient way by most (Windows-based) desktop imaging applications, most nostable red-eye removal, color enhancement, ... . But I guess this is not "just" about writing scripts but rather about finding good algorithms to implement in scripts...

lavinia*s edited this topic ages ago.

tuxcomputers says:

lavinia*s wrote:

it's off topic, but is there anywhere where i can read about how to install such plugins? (sorry for hijacking the thread)

It's not really that off-topic.

There are plugins and there are scripts, plugins are like a little mini program to add functionality that does not already exist in GIMP, like Davids Batch Processor or the Focus Blur plugin.

Scripts are more like macros and use the functionality already built in to GIMP (or provided with another script) to do the effect you want.

To do the install all you need to do is copy it to the appropriate sub-directory and when GIMP next starts it will see the new plug-in/script and it will be available to use.

There are two locations you can put these add ons, in the user location making it available to just that user or in the global directory. For the locations to place the plugins have a look at the Focus Blur link above. To see where to put the scripts check the instructions for the Split tone tutorial.

Kansas Image Maker says:

This may sound like a dumb question but are scripts like photoshop actions? If so how do you make them. I use photoshop actions all the time and lack of actions is one reason I don't use gimp much. If I could easily do actions and batch processing like in photoshop I would love to use gimp more.

ages ago

tuxcomputers says:

Yes scripts are like Photoshop actions in that it replays a series of steps to automate the manipulation.

The difference is that you cannot "record" what you are doing to play it back later. It is a programming language "scheme" and for new begineers, it sucks. Scheme uses a syntax that takes quite a bit of getting used to, (action first second) so 3 + 4 is written (+ 3 4)

The advantage is that it is much much more powerful and flexible. I don't have an experience with Photoshop actions but one GIMP script can call another script. You can have conditional statements, you can read image paramaters and base your calculations on that figure.

paulwb says:

tuxcomputers: of course. My steps:

1) crop the image (or scale it down)

2) a thin white border

3) a thin black border

(would be great to be able to adjust the colour and the thikness)

3) resize canvas to original size, insert original photo as layer behind the other ones and darken it reducing brightness.

But for me it would be much more interesting to be able to create borders around layers. Steps:

1) go to the layer

2) layer -> layer to boundary size, make it $x pixel bigger and centered.

3) select the transparent area of with the magic wand.

4) fill the selection with colour $y.

Well, step 3 and 4 will only work if you have a layer without transparent areas. To make it correct, I would have to get the selection by selecting all the layer and substract the centered rectangular which is $x pixel smaller.

Is this difficult with to implement?

tuxcomputers says:

Ok new script is available here

These are the steps it does:

1. Duplicate background

2. Reduce background brightness

3. Add layer in pos 1, using FG colour

4. Select all

5. Shrink selection by border size

6. Add layer mask of selection

7. Add layer in pos 1, using BG colour

8. Shrink selection by Outer size

9. Add layer mask of selection

10. Shrink selection by inner size

11. Add layer mask to Original of selection

12. Select none

The result:

Originally posted ages ago.

tuxcomputers edited this topic ages ago.

paulwb says:

Thank you! Great. :-)

ages ago

tuxcomputers says:

You know I did this script twice, once using one method, then I realised a much easier/shorter way of doing it, deleted the first one and re-wrote it from the ground up.

Have you tried the script? It allows you to set:

1. The outer edge size

2. The amount of brightness reduction on the outer edge

3. The outer border colour and size

4. The inner border colour and size

One thing I am not happy with is the last step of the script resets the foreground colour and background colour to Black and White. I plan on reading what the current colours are and resetting them to those when the script is finished.

ages ago

Jean-Pierre Bucciol says:

To save your time finding the procedures to call, you can read and restore the foreground and background colors with:

(set! MyForeground (car (gimp-context-get-foreground)))

(set! MyBackground (car (gimp-context-get-background)))

at the beginning, and

(gimp-context-set-foreground MyForeground)

(gimp-context-set-background MyBackground)

at the end.

Error: set!: unbound variable: outerLayer

I just updated the trans-border script, I was getting it to select all and then shrinking the selection. The shrinking took a while to process so I have changed it to selecting a rectangle, it starts at the border corner and is as big as the image minus the border top, bottom and sides.

It speeds up the script quite considerably for the same results.

As for the problem in the 2.3 version I have heard they are changing from Script-Fu to Tiny-Fu and most scripts will need a little tweaking. I will wait until 2.3 becomes stable and released as 2.4 before converting, sorry.

tuxcomputers says:

someotherbob wrote:

hotkeys to scale brush size up and down (ala photoshop [ & ] keys) . I tried the resizebrush script and it didn't work, plus I don't want to go to the menu.

I asked the exact same thing. The steps are as follows:

1. File / Preferences.

2. Interface

3. Configure Keyboards shortcuts.

4. Context

5. Set Increase Radius and Decrease radius to [ and ].

6. Create and/or select a custom brush. It can be any size because you will be using the brackets to set the size.

chimphappyhour says:

How about this translated into a gimp script. It's the steps from an action for PS that makes images look like something made by a guy by the name of Dave Hill (he has a web page, I just don't have the address handy). Anyway, here are the steps that were provided to me from the PS action:

>I got much of the technical content for this action from a posting by Omar Casasola on flickr. I added the history palette step and the fade command to replace his use of selection because I thought my approach was more elegant and suitable for a PS Action. If you open the Action in the Action Palette so you can see the various steps in it and you can tick the boxes to make it ask for a user intervention on a lot of the steps below, so you could tweak the settings more or experiment

The steps in the action are:

1) Duplicate the layer on the LAYER pallette?Go to FILTER - OTHER - HIGH PASS type 4.0 for RADIUS?on the LAYERS pallette choose vivid light for the blending mode?Now flatten the image.

2) Duplicate the layer on the LAYER pallette?Go to FILTER - OTHER - HIGH PASS type 6.9 for RADIUS?on the LAYERS pallette choose color for the blending mode?Set opacity to 40%?Now flatten the image.

3) DUPLICATE LAYER on layer pallette?FILTER - BLUR - GAUSSIAN BLUR 9.4 pixels?FILTER - NOISE - ADD NOISE 3%

This is the point in the History palette that I select at the end of the action - its the last step before sharpening so if you want to tone down the sharpening around features like eyes etc then painting this history point with the history brush will achieve that.

4) Unsharp Mask?AMOUNT 100%?RADIUS 30.0 pixels?THRESHOLD 0

5) fade Unsharp Mask

I tick this to make it a user defined step in the action so you can increase or lower the effect to suit.

6) Select History Brush and select the history step in 3) above

fearful summer [deleted] says:

Would it be possible to write a script that would apply the same levels and/or curves to a set of pictures?

In the levels dialog and in the curves dialog, there is an option to save the curve or level to a file. Often I need to apply the same curve to a batch of pictures and would love to be able to automate the process.

Currently, I adjust the first one, save the curve (or levels) to a file, then open the next picture, open the curve dialog, open the saved curve, hit OK, save the file, close it and repeat.

I imagine that this would be a gimp script that is run only on the command line, but if there's a way to do this to a bunch of pictures at once in the GUI, that'd be great too.

Thanks,

Michael Moore

PhotoComiX says:

mike cash

fencepost

That is exactly a "contrast mask" script there are already for gimp 2.4, as this

www.tankedup-imaging.com/gimp/script-fu/create-contrast-m...

and then is maybe better to avoid to merge layer at the end

Script can't offer a preview, maintain the layers allow to fine tune the result .

will be nice a similar script but with added option to use the REAL overlay mode.

That called "overlay mode" in gimp is not Overlay but a clone of Soft light mode...you can try if you don't believe you will always get identical result, is a bug know from 2004. by mistake overlay mode in gimp is a clone of soft light mode ( anyway result of both mode should be quite similar...

problem is that in gimp are identical )

Back to the contrast mask will be nice have the first gimp "contrast mask " script that may use the REAL overlay mode.

Is possible manually in this way

1) duplicate

B) move the duplicate layer under the original layer( for this may be needed add a alpha layer to the bg layer )

2)desaturate and invert the duplicate

3) apply gaussian blur on the duplicate

4) now the trick change the mode of the ORIGINAL layer that now is on top to Hard Light

that is it !

basically you have a equivalent of "REAL" overlight mode by

1 switching position of top and BG layers

2 top layer in hard light mode

ages ago

PhotoComiX says:

the algorithms used are equivalent,always they give same results, that of "soft light" algorithm

bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=162395.

result of the "true" overlay is similar but not equal ,how much similar that depend from the images

But script fu that do exactly what asked by Mike Cash are already done

But none use overlay, all use the mislabeled clone of soft light

as in this contrast mask script

--------------------------------------------------------------------------

; ContrastMask is a script-fu script for The GIMP

;

; Description: adds a contrast mask to the active layer based on the

; gimpguru.org tutoral located at

; www.gimpguru.org/Tutorials/ContrastMask/

;

; Last changed: 01/10/2006

;

; --------------------------------------------------------------------

;

; This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify

; it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by

; the Free Software Foundation; either version 2 of the License, or

; (at your option) any later version.

;

; This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,

; but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of

; MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE. See the

; GNU General Public License for more details.

;

; You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License

; along with this program; if not, write to the Free Software

; Foundation, Inc., 675 Mass Ave, Cambridge, MA 02139, USA.

;

(define (script-fu-contrast-mask image drawable blurhoriz blurvert)

(set! contlayer (car (gimp-layer-copy drawable 1)))

(gimp-image-add-layer image contlayer -1)

(gimp-layer-set-name contlayer "Contrast Mask")

(gimp-desaturate contlayer)

(gimp-invert contlayer)

(plug-in-gauss-iir2 1 image contlayer blurhoriz blurvert)

(gimp-layer-set-mode contlayer OVERLAY-MODE)

(gimp-displays-flush)

)

(script-fu-register

"script-fu-contrast-mask"

"/Script-Fu/Utils/Contrast Mask"

"Applies a Contrast Mask to reduce overall contrast, and bring out more detail in highlights and shadows."

"Ian Blew"

"copyright 2006, Ian Blew"

"January 13, 2006"

""

SF-IMAGE "Image" 0

SF-DRAWABLE "Drawable" 0

SF-VALUE "Blur Horizontal" "15"

SF-VALUE "Blur Vertical" "15"

)

Originally posted ages ago.

PhotoComiX (a group admin) edited this topic ages ago.

fencepost says:

Thanks, foto!

Mike, the script fotocomics posted above is pretty much what you've requested with the exception that it sets the blur at 15 rather than 5. If you would like to specify 5 instead of the 15, just change the number 15 in the SF-VALUE "Blur Horizontal" "15" to 5 and likewise do the same for the Vertical blur value.

If this doesn't do what you would like and you want something else, I'll do my best to help....I'm pretty new to scripting, so my knowledge is somewhat limited.

@fotocomics: are you still needing a script for the steps you requested in a previous post?

fencepost says:

You're welcome, Mike!

@fotocomics: Your original contrast mask script request is finished. Would you like it to be installed in a specific menu location? Additionally, I've got to figure out a name for this script. If you'll notice in the above script, it's also named contrast mask (script-fu-contrast-mask). If I refer to yours by the same name AND you have both scripts installed on your system, GIMP will have problems and may not run either. So, would you like me to call it something else or leave it as 'script-fu-contrast-mask'? If I leave it as such, you'll need to take out your other script to avoid conflicts. By the way, you can't just rename the script, the script itself has to be changed.

Let me know.

Art

fencepost says:

No problem. I'll do my best about that specific placement, but I can't guarantee it will work. But, we'll see! ;)

(I just did a quick check and don't see a "Photo" menu under my Filters Menu. Is that a default? OR are you just wanting me to add a "Photo" menu under Filters?)

As far as the naming issue I brought up, here's what I mean. In the example here, we're discussing contrast masks. In the define section of the above script you posted, there are two references in that script that look like this: 'script-fu-contrast-mask' One is at the top under the "define" block, the other at the bottom under the "register" block. If I (or anyone for that matter) were to create a script using that same reference (script-fu-contrast-mask) in the define/register sections and I had another script in my scripts folder that jad the same information in the define/register blocks, GIMP would not act right. Not sure if GIMP would pick one over the other or if neither would work, but there would be a conflict. So, even if you changed the "file name" (ie.....contrast-mask.scm for one and Photocomix-ContrastMask.scm for the other), there would be a conflict because GIMP is trying to register to script-fu's with the same "define/register" information. So, I'll just add your name into the define/register blocks and all will be good! ;)

Don't know if that makes complete sense, and since I'm still pretty new to scripting I can't explain it properly, but that, in essence, is what will happen.

Art

fencepost says:

No, problem, it actually won't take me too much longer....should have it up by this afternoon.

BTW, I've noticed that the board has truncated the menu path listed in my post and the script you posted a few days ago. I copied and pasted my script into Notepad and I couldn't get GIMP to recognize it. It took me forever to realize that the board is removing the *Image* tag from the scripts. That's something that needs to be in the script because it tells GIMP where to place it. Not really sure why the board is doing this, but it's not there and if someone tries to copy/paste these scripts, they won't work correctly.

Maybe it's not a good idea to post scripts here (or if someone knows a workaround, that would be greatly appreciated)

Art

fencepost says:

While I understand what you're saying, I have a bit of a different outlook. Here's my take: I consider the single downloads of multiple scripts to be like a grab bag. You know you're probably gonna get some goodies when you look inside the bag, but you don't really know until you get in there and start sorting things out, which can take some time. Plus, there might not be any assistance if something doesn't work quite right. Even if the scm file contains a URL/email address where the author can be reached, some folks just don't know that.

But, if I post a download to my dA site, a prospective user can go there, see a preview of the script's output, get a good description of how/what it does and can send me a message if they need help.

I certainly have no problem any of my scripts being included in the big download, and I'll definitely support that effort. But, I'm very big on personalized service and assisting those who run into snags. I've had a number of tutorials posted on forums around that web that won't/don't/can't offer assistance when users have questions. I feel that's unfair to those needing help. Since I can't be in all places at all times, I like having a central location where users can talk with me directly.

But, as I said, I will gladly allow any of my scripts that are deemed worthy of inclusion into the big download pack. However, I still want folks to be able to view them in my "backyard."
